document.docAuthor: Bloszyk, Jerzy & Stachowiak, Marcin & Halliday, Bruce
document.docTitle: Two new species of Cilliba von Heyden from Poland, with discussion of the Cilliba cassidea (Hermann) species complex (Acari: Mesostigmata: Uropodina: Cillibidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species of Cilliba von Heyden from Poland, with discussion of the Cilliba cassidea (Hermann) species complex (Acari: Mesostigmata: Uropodina: Cillibidae)

paragraph.emphasis:
Two new species of
Cilliba
von Heyden from Poland ,

with discussion of the
Cilliba cassidea (Hermann)
species complex ( Acari : Mesostigmata : Uropodina : Cillibidae )

subSection.paragraph:
JERZY BLOSZYK 1,2 , MARCIN STACHOWIAK 1 & BRUCE HALLIDAY 3
1
Department of Animal Taxonomy and Ecology, A. Mickiewicz University, Umultowska 89, 61614 Pozna
ń,
Poland ; email: bloszyk@amu.edu.pl;

2
Natural History Collections, Faculty of Biology Umultowska 89, 61–614 Pozna
ń,
Poland ; email: bloszyk@amu.edu.pl;

Cilliba cassideasimilis
sp. nov. (
Figures 9–22
)................................... 13

Two new species of mites are described from Europe on the basis of all developmental stages:
Cilliba cassideasimilis
sp. nov. and
C. rafalskii
sp. nov. ( Acari : Uropodina : Cillibidae ). Both of these species have been misidentified in the past as the closely related species
C. cassidea
, but these three species can be distinguished using morphological characters. Data on their geographical distribution and some remarks about ecology of both species are presented and discussed. New records of mites of the genus
Cilliba
are given.

Cilliba
von Heyden ( Acari : Uropodina : Cillibidae ) is a genus of about 15 species of large brown mites with circular body shape that are found throughout Europe in soil, leaf litter, moss and grass. The best known species is
C. cassidea (
Hermann, 1804
)
, which is mentioned in many studies of the ecology of European forests. However, this and related species have been involved in some nomenclatural and taxonomic confusion which undermines the value of those ecological studies.

The species involved in the present study were first mentioned by
Hermann ( 1804 )
, who described the species
Notaspis cassideus
from moss in France . The genus
Cilliba
was then described by von
Heyden ( 1826 )
, with
N. cassideus
as its type species.
Haller ( 1881 )
described the species
Uropoda clavus
, which is now regarded as a synonym of
C. cassidea
.
Berlese ( 1882 )
referred to this species as
Discopoma cassidea (Hermann)
, and
Michael ( 1894 )
as
Cilliba ( Discopoma ) cassidea
. Since then this well­known species has been referred to many times, either as
Cilliba cassidea
or
Uropoda ( Cilliba ) cassidea
.

The next representatives of the genus
Cilliba
were not described until almost 50 years later. These were
C. circularis Trägårdh ( 1931 )
from Iceland and
C. insularis
Willmann ( 1939 )
from Spain . Three species mentioned by Lombardini, namely
C. antennurelloides
Lombardini, 1943
,
C. tripliciterscutata
Lombardini, 1943
and
C. foroliviensis
Lombardini, 1961
, have never been verified, whereas another species,
C. coprophila
Womersley, 1960
from Australia proved to be a representative of the genus
Uroobovella (
Athias­Binche & Bloszyk, 1988
)
.

Hirschmann & Zirngiebl­Nicol ( 1969 a)
considered
Cilliba
to be a subgenus of
Uropoda
, and described the next seven species in the genus:
U . ( C .) athiasae
,
U . ( C .) cassidoidea
,
U . ( C .) erlangensis
,
U . ( C .) franzi
,
U . ( C .) sellnicki
,
U . ( C .) stammeri
and
U . ( C .) woelkei
.
Hirschmann & Zirngiebl­Nicol ( 1969 b)
further added
Uropoda ( Cilliba ) cassidea
var. minima
.

Athias­Binche ( 1981, 1983 a,b) conducted a series of studies of the ecology of uropodid mite communities in forest reserves in southern France , and mentioned a species by the name of
Cilliba massanae
Athias­Binche, 1980
. However, this is not an available name because it was published in a thesis, and is therefore excluded by Article 9 ( 6 ) of the second edition of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, which was in force at the time. The species referred to as "
Cilliba massanae
" in those studies has been identified as
C. erlangensis Hirschmann & Zirngiebl­Nicol
(J. Bloszyk, personal observations).

U . ( C .) sopronensis
Wiśniewski & Hirschmann, 1990
was described from the tunnels of a scolytid beetle in Hungary . However, this species was regarded by Bloszyk ( 1999 ) as a synonym of
C. sellnicki Hirschmann & Zirngiebl­Nicol.

Bloszyk ( 1984 )
, in a paper concerning the influence of altitude on the distribution of Uropodina , mentioned two species of
Cilliba
,
C. cassideasimilis
and
C. rafalskii
, with no morphological descriptions. According to the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, both names are nomina nuda (
Wiśniewski & Hirschmann, 1993
). In subsequent publications, Bloszyk ( e. g . 1995, 1999 ) referred to these species as
Cilliba
species I and
Cilliba
species II.

Bloszyk ( 1983
, 1999) pointed out that
Cilliba cassidea
recorded from Poland and regarded as widely distributed and common in Europe, is in fact a complex of several closely related taxa. In a collection of over 11,000 soil samples from various geographical regions and habitats in Poland and other European countries, large numbers of specimens of
C. cassidea
and related species have been found. This material includes the two new species previously mentioned by
Bloszyk ( 1984 )
. Due to their great morphological similarity, those species have previously been identified by various authors from Poland and other central European countries as
C. cassidea
. Hence, information regarding distribution, ecological requirements and biology of
C. cassidea
in central Europe is misleading, because it includes three separate species.

The purpose of this paper is to resolve this situation by describing two new species of
Cilliba
, and presenting details of the morphological differences between them and
C. cassidea
. The redescription of
C. cassidea
given by
Athias­Binche ( 1977 )
and the names of the two new species introduced by
Bloszyk ( 1984 )
are retained for the sake of simplicity and clarity.

The raw material for this study consists of 12,899 soil samples collected from various types of habitat (forests, open and disturbed habitats) collected during 50 years of fieldwork by Prof. Jan Rafalski and his colleagues. Samples were collected using standard methods for acarological studies. In the 498 samples examined, 2,168 individuals from the study species were found. Morphological features were measured using the program for biometric measurements Lupa 2.0. Localities in Poland were determined according to the UTM system ( 10 squares per 10 km ). Scanning photomicrographs were prepared in the Electron Microscope Laboratory of Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań ( Poland ).

The short morphological description of the developmental stages of
C. cassidea
was based on the detailed study of
Athias­Binche ( 1977 )
and analysis of new material. The distribution of the species was determined by study of material from Germany , France , Norway , Poland and Spain , and summarised in a series of maps of Europe.

The morphological terminology is that of
Evans & Till ( 1979 )
,
Athias­Binche & Evans ( 1981 )
,
Bloszyk & Athias­Binche ( 1998 )
,
Bloszyk & Halliday ( 2000 )
and
Bloszyk et al. ( 2005 )
. Dorsal and ventral poroidotaxy and location of lyrifssures are as presented by
Athias­Binche ( 1977 )
(variability of these features has not been analysed). The system of leg chaetotaxy is that of
Bloszyk & Leoniak ( 1986
, 1995). Abbreviations: Mnt.— mountain; Res.—reserve; UTM—Universal Transverse System.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species:
Notaspis cassideus
Hermann, 1804
, by original designation

Diagnosis : Typical representative of higher Uropodoidea sensu
Athias­Binche & Evans ( 1981 )
, with well marked pedofossal grooves (FP I–FP IV). Cuticle well sclerotised, brown in colour; body flat, subcircular, cuticle smooth or punctate, may be sculptured centrally with small pits. Marginal shield broad with ca 6 pairs of lyrifissures ( id ), separated from dorsal shield or fused with it anteriorly. Marginal setae numerous, short, hook­like. Submarginal setae simple, shorter than dorsal setae. Dorsal setae simple or lanceolate, each accompanied by a circular porus. Five pairs of simple sternal setae ( st
1
–st
5
), and three pairs of lyrifissures:
iv
1
near camerostome,
iv
2
near setae st
5
and
iv
3
below pedofossal grooves IV. Epigynium of female large, tongue­shaped, articulated below the level of coxae IV, ornamented, with one pair of lyrifissures located near the posterior edge of the shield ( ig ), covering endogynial shield ( sg ) and endogynial sac ( seg ). Operculum ( opr ) of male oval, surrounded posteriorly by semicylindrical postgenital element ( pg ), with one pair of eugenital setae ( plg ), situated at a level between coxae III and IV. Five pairs of simple ventral setae (
v
1
–v
5
). Two pairs of simple adanal setae ( Ad
1
, Ad
2
) and unpaired postanal seta ( Pa ). Each pair of ventral setae accompanied by circular porus. Idiosomal chaetotaxy for immatures and adults as in
Table 1
. Peritremes short, Vshaped, without poststigmatic section, located near the margins of the body. Two pairs of lyrifissures ( il ) and several pairs of globular glands ( gv , gl ) located in and between pedofossal grooves and on opisthosoma. Tritosternum 6 ­branched, with broad base. Hypostomal setae h
1
longer than the others, h
2
short, h
3
= h
4
, h
4
longer than h
2
. Tarsus I without claws, but with long terminal seta; leg chaetotaxy as in
Table 2
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Idiosomal chaetotaxy in larva (L), protonymph (Pn), deutonymph (Dn) and adult (A) of the genus
Cilliba
(after Athias­Binche, 1977): st—sternal series; v, Ad—ventral and adanal series (excluding unpaired seta Pa ); v—total number of ventral setae; j, J—dorsal series; z, Zmediolateral series; s, S—lateral series; r, R—submarginal series.; d—total number of dorsal

subSubSection.paragraph: setae.

Material examined . New collections of this species from Spain , France , Great Britain , Ireland , Germany , Poland , and Turkey , and information from the literature were used to determine the distribution of this species in Europe (
Fig. 1
). Germany : 11 Ψ, 9 ɗ, Karlsruhe,
49 °00'00" N
,
08° 40 '00" W
, [ 5 samples,
1980–1982
]. France : 26 Ψ, 46 ɗ, Lyon, Belfort, [ 5 samples,
1978–1980
]. Ireland : 11 Ψ, 4 ɗ, Killarney National Park,
52 °00'00" N
,
09° 50 '00" W
, [ 3 samples, 1981 ]. Poland (
Fig. 2
): 3 Ψ, Szczyrk, CA 50 [ 2 samples, 1976 ]; 2 Ψ, 3 ɗ, Świnia Góra Res., DB 85 [ 1 sample, 1973 ]; 4 Ψ, 3 ɗ, Bieszczady, FV 16 [ 1 sample, 1977 ]; 7 Ψ, 21 ɗ, Przydarlów near Pyrzyce, VU 67,87 , [ 2 samples, 1973 ]; 1 Ψ, 1 ɗ, Puszcza Bukowa near Szczecin, VV 70 , [ 1 sample, 1973 ]; 1 Ψ, 3 ɗ, Kolobrzeg, WA 30 , [ 1 sample, 1978 ]; 43 Ψ, 30 ɗ, 16 deutonymphs, 1 protonymph, Karkonosze Mnts., WS 33,44 , 52,64 , [ 6 samples,
1973–1976
]; 3 Ψ, 2 ɗ, Suliszewo near Drawsko Pomorskie, WV 53 , [ 1 sample, 1978 ]; 4 Ψ, 4 ɗ, Grzybno near Slawno, XA 0 2 , [ 1 sample, 1978 ]; 10 Ψ, 3 ɗ, Stolowe Mnts., XR 26 , XS 21,23 , 41 [ 4 samples,
1970–1976
].

Cilliba cassidea

subSubSection.paragraph: Female . Strongly sclerotised, brown.

Dorsal idiosoma (
Fig. 3
A). Length 849–1104 m , width 820–1053 m (after Athias­
Binche ( 1977 )
,
Hirschmann & Zirngiebl­Nicol ( 1969 c)
and
Wiśniewski & Hirschmann ( 1993 ))
. In material examined, length 849–952 m , mean 902 m , width 820–915 m , mean 868 m , n = 54 . Dorsal shield subcircular, with characteristic ornamentation of scattered circular pits in the posterior half. Marginal shield smooth, with numerous lyrifissures ( id ), completely separated from dorsal shield. Dorsal setae numerous, simple ( ca 50 µm long). Submarginal setae simple ( ca 20 µm long), marginal setae numerous, very short, hook­like.

Ventral idiosoma (
Fig. 3
B) smooth, except for small pits on endopodal shields and anterior part of opisthosoma. Sternal shield with 5 pairs of simple setae; st
1
located in front of anterior edge of epigynium, st
2
–st
5
lateral to epigynium. Epigynium tongue­shaped (length 189–231 m , width 120–147 m ), covered with numerous small oval pits in the central part. Opisthosoma smooth, except region below epigynium covered with pits. Ventral setae (
v
1
–v
5
) simple,
v
1
=
v
2
; setae
v
4
and v
5
located on small mounds. Adanal setae Ad
1
very short, Ad
2
=
2 x
Ad
1
. Unpaired seta Pa = Ad
1
. Anal opening small, oval. Peritremes V­shaped, length ca
161 m .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 . Distribution of
Cilliba cassidea
in Poland, based on 11,000 soil samples. A,
C. cassidea
present; B,
C. cassidea
not recorded.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
(
Fig. 4
) Epistome narrow, laterally serrated. Hypostomal setae h
1
very long ( ca 76 m ), simple; h
2
short ( ca 19 m ), robust, serrated; h
3
short ( ca 26 m ), less robust than h
2
, distally serrated; h
4
short ( ca 29 m ), curved, robust, laterally serrated. Hypostomal surface covered with fine denticles of various size; denticles grouped in single row at the level of setae h
2
and distributed irregularly between setae h
3
–h
4
.

Hypostomal groove finely serrated (
Fig. 4
A). Ventral setae pv
1
–pv
2
on palp trochanters robust, pv
1
ca 26 m long, robust, distally serrated, pv
2
ca 16 m long, simple. Chelicerae of average length, fixed digit with globular sensillus and small denticles on the internal surface, movable digit shorter than fixed digit, with single denticle on the internal surface (
Fig. 4
C). Tritosternum 6 ­branched, with broad base, laciniae serrated finely on distal ends (
Fig. 4
D).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Cilliba cassidea
, from Athias­Binche 1977; by permission from Acarologia . A, female, dorsal idiosoma; B, female, ventral idiosoma; C, male, intercoxal region.

subSubSection.paragraph: Legs. Proximal seta ad on leg I in the form of a short, robust process. Dorsal setae on tibia I robust, short. Setae al , pl and distal setae pd on tarsus II–IV serrated.
Male. Strongly sclerotised, brown.

Dorsal idiosoma. Length 849–1095 m , width 830–1007 m (after
Athias­Binche ( 1977 )
,
Hirschmann & Zirngiebl­Nicol ( 1969 c)
and
Wiśniewski & Hirschmann ( 1993 ))
. In material examined, length 849–934 m , mean 891 m , width 830–905 m , mean 868 m , n = 44 . Ornamentation and chaetotaxy as for female.

Ventral idiosoma (
Fig. 3
C). Sternal region, endopodal shields and anterior part of opisthosoma ornamented with small circular pits. Operculum oval ( 76–98
x 49
–64 m), located at a level between coxae III and IV. Sternal setae st
1
–st
3
very short, st
4
–st
5
longer. Three pairs of glands located near setae st
3
. Ornamentation and chaetotaxy of opisthosoma and peritremes as for female.

Gnathosoma
(
Fig. 4
B). Epistome as for female. Hypostomal groove finely serrated. Hypostomal setae h
1
ca 44 m , simple; h
2
ca 12 m , simple; h
3
short ( 4 µm), blunt, rounded; h
4
ca 17 m , curved, pinnate laterally and serrated distally.

Legs . Structure and chaetotaxy as for female, except some sexual dimorphism of legs I visible: setae al and pl on trochanter robust, setae al on femur and genu robust, dorsal setae of genu and tibia robust, short. Setae pd and pl on femur III robust. Setae al , pl , ad and pd on legs II–III serrated. Setae pl and pd on tarsus IV serrated.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Cilliba cassidea
. A, female, hypostome; B, male, hypostome; C, female, chelicera (paraxial view); D, female, tritosternum.

subSubSection.paragraph: Deutonymph . Partly sclerotised, colour yellowish to lightly brown.

Dorsal idiosoma (
Fig. 5
A). Length 775–993 µm, width 700–885 µm. Dorsal shield subcircular, smooth, marginal shield absent. Anterior end of idiosoma with single cuticular process. Dorsal setae numerous, simple; some of them accompanied by circular pores. Between the setae ca 6 pairs of dorsal lyrifissures ( id ). Submarginal setae simple. Marginal setae very numerous, short, hook­like.

Ventral idiosoma (
Fig. 5
B). Sternal shield amphora­shaped, with distinctly widened base, smooth, extending behind coxae IV, with five pairs of short, simple setae ( st
1
– st
5
). Two pairs of lyrifissures:
iv
1
near camerostome,
iv
2
below setae st
5
. Ventral shield wide, smooth, with five pairs of simple ventral setae; all setae of equal length. Setae
v
1
,
v
2
and v
5
accompanied by circular pores. One pair of lyrifissures (
iv
3
) located near setae
v
2
.
Anal shield triangular, with anal opening covered by a small valve and a pair of very short setae Ad
1
. Setae Ad
2
and Pa on shield surrounding the anus, Ad
2
=
2 x
Pa . Peritreme long, with characteristic curve at level of coxae II, without poststigmatic extension, prestigmatic section reaching camerostome, stigmata at level of coxae III.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Cilliba cassidea
, from Athias­Binche 1977; by permission from Acarologia. A, deutonymph, dorsal idiosoma; B, deutonymph, ventral idiosoma.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
. Epistome narrow and serrated, distally bifid. Hypostome similar to female. Tritosternum 6 ­branched, with broad base.
Legs . Structure and chaetotaxy as for female.
Protonymph . Weakly sclerotised, colour white to yellowish.

Dorsal idiosoma (
Fig. 6
A). Length 587–640 µm, width 472–550 µm. Podonotal shield pear­shaped, large, smooth. Mesopodal shields small, elongate; mesonotal shields irregular in shape; pygidial shield crescent­shaped; all shields smooth. Setae
j 3–6
simple, short, inserted on podonotal shield;
Z 1 , J 1
and
J 2
longer, inserted on pleura between podonotal and pygidial shield. Setae
j 2
,
z 2
,
z 3
,
s 3–6
,
S 1
,
Z 2
and
J 4
short, positioned submarginally; only
J 4
on small protuberances. Setae
j 1
,
s 2
,
r 3–5
,
R 1
,
R 3
,
S 3
,
S 4
,
Z 3
,
Z 4
and
J 5
long, massive, inserted on protuberances along the margin of the idiosoma, apparently supporting a soft, membranous fringe surrounding the idiosoma. Several idiosomal setae with associated circular pores.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Cilliba cassidea
, from Athias­Binche 1977; by permission from Acarologia . A, protonymph, dorsal idiosoma; B, protonymph, ventral idiosoma.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ventral idiosoma (
Fig. 6
B). Weakly sclerotised, smooth. Sternal shield poorly defined, with three pairs of simple sternal setae. Metapodal shields elongate, smooth. Opisthogastric integument with four pairs of simple ventral setae (
v
1
,
v
3
–v
5
);
v
1
and v
3
anterior to the ventri­anal shield,
v
4
and v
5
lateral to ventri­anal shield. Three pairs of glands open on soft ventral pleura near metapodal shields ( gv
1
, gv
2
and gl
6
). Ventri­anal shield oval, smooth, with anal opening, a pair of setae Ad and an unpaired seta Pa ; Ad = ½ Pa . Peritreme short, simple, without poststigmatic section (prestigmatic section straight); stigmata at level of coxae III.

Gnathosoma and legs
. Not analysed.
Larva . Unsclerotised, colour whitish.

Dorsal idiosoma (
Fig. 7
A). Length ca 476 µm, width ca 344 µm. Anterior end of body with three indistinct cuticular processes. Podonotal shield lanceolate, smooth. Two pairs of sclerites located below the podonotum. Dorsal setae
j 1 –j 6
and
J 2
inserted para­axially;
j 1
long, recurved,
j 2 –j 6
simple, short, located on the podonotum,
J 2
bifid, inserted on pleura between podonotal and pygidial shields. Setae
z 2
,
z 3
,
s 4
,
S 1
and
Z 2
on lateral part of idiosoma;
z 2
,
z 3
and
s 4
robust, longer than j ­series setae, inserted on the edge of podonotum,
S 1
and
Z 2
positioned on pleura. Setae
R 1 –R 3
,
S 4
,
Z 3
,
Z 4
,
J 4
and
J 5
massive, inserted on protuberances along the margin of the body; all bifid, except
S 4
and
Z 4
, which are spinose.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female . Well sclerotised, colour brown.

Dorsal idiosoma (
Fig. 11
, 13 A, B). Length 775–828 µm (mean 808 µm), width 746–814 µm (mean 769 µm) (n = 31 ). Dorsal shield subcircular, smooth, with characteristic ornamentation of scattered circular pits in the posterior half. Marginal shield smooth, with numerous lyrifissures ( id ), fused with dorsal shield at anterior end of body. Dorsal setae numerous, thick, simple (mean 55 µm). Submarginal setae simple (mean 19 µm), marginal setae very numerous, short, hook­like.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11 .
Cilliba cassideasimilis
sp. nov. , female, dorsal idiosoma.

Ventral idiosoma (
Figs 12
A, 13 C, D). Sternal shield smooth, with five pairs of sternal setae ( st
1
– st
5
); st
1
above the anterior edge of epigynium, and st
2
– st
5
lateral to the epigynium ( st
1
= 6 µm, st
2
= 10 µm, st
3
= 15 µm, st

subSection.paragraph:
Cilliba cassideasimilis
and
C. rafalskii
are very similar to
C. cassidea
in size, shape and ornamentation. However, the differences between these species are distinct enough to warrant their recognition as separate species.
Table 3
presents the morphological differences between the adult stages of these species. Unfortunately, due to insufficient numbers of individuals in the material collected, and problems with obtaining the earliest developmental stages of the newly described species, we are unable to distinguish the protonymphs and larvae. Detailed biometric analysis of morphological features supported by statistical analysis of the data must be done to address this problem. The use of SEM microphotographs to emphasize selected morphological characteristics as used here, will be a valuable addition to conventional optical microscopy for this purpose.

The close morphological similarity of these species has caused a complicated series of misidentifications in the literature, as shown in the synonymy and bibliography of the two new species. Examples are
C. cassidea sensu
Bloszyk & Olszanowski ( 1986 : 193 )
=
C. cassideasimilis
;
C. cassidea sensu
Gwiazdowicz ( 1999 : 39 )
=
C. cassideasimilis
;
C. cassideasimilis sensu
Bloszyk ( 1984 : 70 )
=
C. rafalskii
;
C. rafalskii
Bloszyk ( 1984 : 70 )
( nomen nudum ) =
C. sellnicki
. In some cases it is not possible to know with any confidence which species was being referred to;
e. g. Uropoda cassidea sensu
Skorupski & Golojuch ( 1996 : 78 )
,
Gwiazdowicz et al. ( 2001
: 70 ).

The specimens of
C. rafalskii
that we examined include
331 females
and no males — the species would appear to be thelytokous. This is in sharp contrast to
C. cassidea
(
42 females
,
70 males
) and
C. cassideasimilis
(
445 females
,
587 males
). Males have been described for nine of the other 12 species in the genus, but are unknown for
C. erlangensis
,
C. franzi
and
C. insularis
.
Norton et al. ( 1993 )
listed
C. erlangensis
and "
C. minor
" (=
Uropoda ( Uropoda ) minor (Berlese))
as suspected of being thelytokous, on the grounds that no males had been seen. The genus
Cilliba
would appear to offer an opportunity to examine the evolutionary relationships between thelytokous and sexually reproducing species within a genus.

We have considered
Cilliba
to be exclusively European. This observation was also made by
Marshall et al. ( 1999 )
.
Farrier & Hennessey ( 1993 )
list some early records of the genus from North America , but the identity of these is very dubious (
Hirschmann & Huţu, 1974
). Some records of
Cilliba
from Mexico have been published (
Vázquez & Klompen, 2001
) but these specimens do not belong to
Cilliba
as defined here (H. Klompen, pers . comm .).
Marais ( 1981 )
described three species of
Cilliba
from Angola , but these do not belong to
Cilliba
either. The shape of their peritremes, morphology of the marginal setae, and opisthosomal chaetotaxy place these species in some other genus, probably undescribed.

subSection.paragraph:
Both the new species are strongly associated with forest habitats (
Table 4
).
Cilliba cassideasimilis
is widely dispersed in Europe (
Fig. 9
), but its distribution is clearly disjunct. It has not been recorded so far from France , despite the existence of suitable habitats and climatic conditions there. It is also unknown from Great Britain , Belgium and the Netherlands , possibly due to extensive deforestation in those areas. In Poland ,
C. cassideasimilis
is the most common and abundant species in the genus (
Fig. 10
), occurring in fir­beech and beech forests in both mountains and lowlands (
Fig. 35
A). Its optimum altitude is below 700 m a.s.l., but it has also been recorded in high mountains (
Fig. 36
A).
C. rafalskii
occurs infrequently at sites distributed over all areas of Poland (
Figs 23
, 24 ). It occupies forest habitats, preferring the litter of oak­hornbeam forests and other multispecies leafy forests (
Fig. 35
B). The optimum altitude for this species is below 500 m a.s.l. (
Fig. 36
B).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 35. Habitat preferences of
Cilliba
spp. A,
Cilliba cassideasimilis
sp. nov. ; B,
C. rafalskii
sp. nov.

subSection.paragraph:
We attempted to characterize the appearance of all developmental stages in particular months of the year in the available samples. Over the whole of Poland , both
C. cassideasimilis
and
C. rafalskii
show no specific period for the presence of their development stages—they can be found during the whole year. More detailed analysis of the demography of these species has been attempted, based on observations of local populations inhabiting the reserves “Las Gr dowy nad Mogielnic ” and “Jakubowo”, near Pniewy (
Bloszyk et al ., 1994
). The analysis proved to be possible only for
C. rafalskii
, since the number of individuals of
C. cassideasimilis
in samples collected from the reserves was too low.

The demography of
C. rafalskii
is characterized by a 1 ­year life cycle. Larval stages were most numerous in September, whereas females with eggs were recorded between June and July (
Fig. 37
). Protonymphs developed from larvae in October–November, and at this stage they seemed to hibernate. In February–March, they metamorphosed into deutonymphs, and converted into adult females in July.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 36. Altitude preferences of
Cilliba
spp. A,
Cilliba cassideasimilis
sp. nov. ; B,
C. rafalskii
sp. nov.

subSection.paragraph:
Wiśniewski & Hirschmann ( 1993 )
listed 16 species of the genus
Cilliba
in Europe. However, because the original descriptions and illustrations of some species are inadequate, further detailed morphological studies of the genus must be done to clarify the identity of these species, in particular of the immature stages. The present paper is a precursor to a larger study of the systematics of the genus
Cilliba
which is now in progress.
